It's nice to see the setters for including problems that rely on technical skill and being precise with movement.  So great job guys!Again, I think the holds could be a lot cleaner as sometimes the chalked up holds are difficult to determine if I'm going the proper route.That's all I got to say and I wish I lived closer to LAB. For any experienced climbers, this is a nice gym I would recommend. As my friend would describe, it's like Disneyland for bouldering.

Great bouldering gym. Awesome Staff! Late one night my friend accidentally left his keys to his ruckus in another friends car and they allowed us to push it inside the building and kept it safe for us until the morning. Thanks for being so cool guys! My only gripe about the gym is that you have to downclimb everything once u get to the top. Sometimes I just want to walk off after exhausting myself up a route and don't want to deal with down climbing something even if it's super easy. I was spoiled by other gyms and their walk offs. I was surprise LAB lacked that feature considering it's a bouldering specific gym.

I'm not a pro rock climber but rock climbing is definitely good exercise! This place is only for boulding. They do not have those ones with ropes. I'm still super beginner at rock climbing.. still at V1. There was a lot of people here on a Friday night. It was $20 for a day pass and $4 for shoes and $1 for chalk. Some V1s were more difficult than others. V0 was fairly easy for me. V2 was pretty impossible for me. Need to work on that arm and upper body strength! Everyone that went here the night I went was really good! When I got tired, I was just observing others boulder. There were some upside down ones and I was just watching a group do this particular V7 one that went upside down. It was amazing to see him accomplish it! It looked so difficult. It definitely gives you motivation to try harder. Everyone is very supportive and it is not embarassing if you cannot do something. I also love that they have quite a few gym things in the workout corner. They have a squatting rack which my friend and I used after rock climbing. I was sore for at least 3 days!

A really cool place to get a full body workout and to take your lady out on a date! There's some nice restaurants right down the block. But be careful, skid row is right around the corner as well. Overall nice staff and a well maintained facility. Will be back again soon!!! Oh, and make sure to buy chalk!!!

I love this gym.  Movement is fluid and tricky at times which makes for great problem solving.  I just wish the grading system was more  consistent. I flash v6 sometimes and get stumped on v4. Some v3's are harder than v5. Other than that the gym is great.  The setters set anything from really powerful overhanging problems to delicate and balance style,  beta intensive problems. Parking is crappy. But if you have psychic abilities it shouldn't be a problem.  Unfortunately i don't have that gift and usually end up parking far and walking.If you come after 5, be prepared to find a packed gym. You might have to wait in line for fresh problems.  But the great thing about bouldering is the camaraderie  i guess. The main reason i go to this gym is because of the future plans of touchstone to have multiple gyms in Los Angeles. I used to be a sport climber...not sure what happened.  Waiting patiently for cliffs of id to open.

LA Boulders is definitely the best climbing gym for bouldering. The facility is clean, well kept, and everyone who goes there is friendly and helpful. I would recommend this gym to anyone who is looking for a great workout and wants to challenge themselves. The gym has a great community feel with people who are ready to help you and encourage you. -Customer service was professional, friendly, and extremely accommodating. Ryan at the front desk helped me to fit my shoes perfectly and get me started. He explained which routes I should try first and gave me some great tips for climbing that helped improve my technique. -Plenty of routes for beginners to extremely experienced climbers. You can find a beginner route on each of the walls and the tape and rocks are easy to follow unlike other gyms I have been to that you struggle to stay on route because the tape and colors aren't clear.  - Facility also has a full gym including free weights, kettle balls, and that stretchy machine thingy that I can't remember the name of. They also have climbing gear that can help you improve your climbing ability and strength. Overall, this is the best gym I have been to and if I lived closer I would definitely get a membership. The day pass for $20 is definitely worth it though and I can get in a great work out and spend a few hours there. -

What fun in the heart of LA'a downtown Loft district! Shockingly, it is literally is adjacent and shares walls to an indoor gun shooting range! By the way, you can buy really cheap bottled water ($0.50) at the gun range since the climbing gym doesn't sell water! The climbing gym is a lot of fun, reasonably priced for first timers and could get you hooked if you want to get a great workout while meeting new, like-minded, fitness affectionato friends! It is not the place for the faint hearted or those who may be fearful of heights or suffer acrophobia!

I have been bouldering in gyms for years now and I have to say this is the nicest gym I have been too! I have been to Rockreation, 3 of the Hangar 18 locations, The ARC, one in AZ, and one in WA. What makes a climbing gym good is so much detail but from my two trips here I have seen that these things are covered. Clean gymA/CFriendly StaffInteresting Problems with fair ratingsReasonable PricingClean Bathroom (with soap and stocked towels or drying machine...shame on you ARC)Friendly vibe from membersPro ShopClearly Marked RoutesI have to say the parking was a little challenging on a Sat but other than that I enjoyed it plenty. It's been a while since I'd been climbing because my local gym is just bad and gross. I look forward to them opening their Pasadena Location SOON!!!

If you're looking for the only climbing gym...- in the entire county that has A/C...- w/ all sorts of bouldering problems neatly set on Walltopia walls...- that is larger than nearly every other climbing gym in LA, OC and the Inland Empire of just bouldering walls...- that is the largest bouldering gym in SoCal (and second in the state, as their corporate sibling's largest is in SF)...- that has more bouldering problems than anyone else except for SF, with fitness equipment, free wifi, towel service...... then you've come to the right place.I travel 45 miles using public transit in most instances to climb here, as I am a member. Don't get me wrong, I support and also have a membership to Hangar 18 Climbing Gyms too, but I split my time almost equally between H18 and LA Boulders. I like solving all sorts of problems from different setters. LA Boulders is as nice of a bouldering gym that money can buy membership with, in SoCal. Enough said. See you there.

Of 20 or so gyms Ive been to this was my favorite. Setting was amazing which is my top priority and although it got a bit crowded the layout is great.  Seemed like a good community. Also the life size Atari replica route blew my mind.

I shopped around yelp to see where I could go for a light session of climbing/bouldering on a lazy President's Day afternoon. This was the perfect place for an amateur like myself and his overzealous gf who was ready to try some V5s on her first trip. The equipment rental and day pass is super reasonably priced ($15 if before 3PM on wkday, $20 otherwise) and $5 for shoe rental. There is lots of wall space with many different levels of difficulty to keep you challenged and entertained. The people there are super enthusiastic and having a great time so it's a good environment with a positive vibe.In response to some of the other reviews, the facilities are coming along nicely. The locker rooms are super nice with showers, lockers (bring your own lock or borrow one in exchange for your ID). They even have treadmills and ellipticals on the second floor between the men and women's locker rooms. Oh, and they have free parking in the back. The lot gets a touch crowded but the fact that they even have the option of free parking is amazing for DTLA.Loved my experience there, and will definitely be coming back.

I really like this climbing gym. it is always clean and well maintained. They change the different climbs regularly as well. I like how their walls are much taller than some other gyms as well. I also like how you can go in the morning and then go again at night, all on the same day pass!! It is the best for Tuesdays and Thursdays. I did not give it 5 stars because they do not have top roping, which is only a minor drawback. If I could give half stars this place would be a 4.5 for sure!

kinda awesome. my soft, milky hands have finally developed the callousness of work and life and my foot now has some weird fat deposit from being smashed up against the stucco-y, sandpaper-y wall one too many times. that said, hubby and i can't wait to go back on buddy day, and hopefully soon, get our own memberships! parking is free although can be difficult at times, and right next to la gun club!
I came here as a guest and been a member ever since (18 months now). Best workout ever. I've never climbed outside or with a rope, but I am strongly considering it now.

I LOVE THIS PLACE. It is the best bouldering gym I've been to by far next to The Factory. I've heard so much about this place and finally being able to go I was definitely not disappointed. The gym is strictly just bouldering. But it offers a massive variety for all ages and for all levels. They have flat, slab and over hang walls with roofs. As well as an enormous arch and other types to provide a better workout. There is also certain areas after you top out and mantle to down climb at so look out for those. They have a good area for a gym and to get a regular workout. The staff is pretty friendly and nice the area is spacious and gives plenty of room for people to climb. I say the only down side is that it can be a bit pricey. My friends and I got there before 3pm and on weekdays it's only $15 if you are there before hand. Shoes cost $4 extra. Fortunately as a climber I already have all my gear so I normally just worry about paying to get in and climb. There's lots of cubbies to put your stuff in and even has lockers upstairs as long as you give them an ID of some sort. I wish I could be there more often but given the drive it can be a hassle. I can't wait to come back again and work and project more climbs!

Super fun boulder gym.  Ratings were accurate and problems were set in super fun ways.  A lot of neat features and the local climber scene is way friendly and supportive.  Will be back when I am in town again!

First time I've reviewed anything. Keep in mind, I visited at 9PM on a Tuesday night and I am not all that good at climbing (I consider myself pretty shitty). First its location - in LA, ease of travel and parking are two musts for success - the gym is not far off the 10 and parking is quite abundant at least when I visited. The gym itself is smaller than Dogpatch but for what it lacks in square footage, it makes up for in pure creativity. With La.B, Touchstone packed an equal if not greater punch to its counterpart in a much smaller space; it uses the entirety of its set up with great efficiency. The gym also does not dwell too long on any one wall type - you don't run into a wave stretching from one end of the gym to the other; the walls pose challenges unto themselves with level changes and progressions that make even a simple problem a bit more technical. The route setting is comparable to Dogpatch of late - challenging sends that do not simply value strength but a proficiency in movement. The setters also give you a lot of variety along the V-scale. The thing I'm most happy about, and this may sound OCD, is that they use tape marking instead of hold color. I know, "who cares?" Apparently I do as color holds seemed to have been the norm in Southern California (Sender One, Hangar 18) but that's not the case with La.B. The time I visited was perfect - the gym was practically empty. I expect this to change as it did with Dogpatch once people start to hear more about La.B. Also, they do not have the free weights up and running yet - they do have a nice area set aside against the front windows - plenty of space for a couple racks and dumbbells (it's probably twice the size of Mission Cliffs' workout space). Treadmills and cardio machines are good to go upstairs though. All in all, I look forward to making a weekly excursion to La.B.
Awesome gym and tons of problems to try out. Everything you could ever climb is there. Most staff was helpful and friendly. Climbers were also friendly.Great place to get a good session in.

If you like bouldering, this is the place for you! It has a bunch of walls where you can climb. There are 8 different difficulty levels (V0 - V7). They are all labeled. This is a great place for both beginners and advanced rock climbers. If you make it to the top of the walls, there's a cool little lounge area with couches, along with an entire yoga areaGood place to go. Try it at least once!

This was my first time here (and first time bouldering) and I absolutely loved it! The environment and people are so positive. There were both beginners and experts here so there's no need to feel like you're the only one who doesn't know what to do(which I did before entering). Plenty of walls for you to climb and plenty courses for every level. The guy at the front desk (I think his name is Joe) was super cool and helpful, letting us know the basics of it all. FYI, I have never been bouldering before and I have absolutely no arm strength whatsoever. I'm the type who gets so tired and bored after lifting weights & feels somewhat weak and intimidated when I'm struggling with 10 lbs while everyone else is at 30+ lbs (I can't even lift the bar alone) that I don't even bother working on arms at the gym. With that being said, my arms are currently so weak and sore from all that climbing which is GREAT. If you don't like working on arms at the gym, this is a great place to build up some muscle.I will definitely come again! Possibly even considering the membership since it's so close by

This place is fun. To bring anyone whenever you feel active. The prices are good it's cheaper earlier in the day. The front desk lady is so nice and so polite I don't know her name but the one with short brown hair she's so helpful. The vibe overall here is great.
Great place to climb - lots of routes, really chill and lots of fun.  Staff is really great (Kevin is very cool) and very helpful.  Really like climbing here!

First time trying our indoor bouldering and now I'm hooked.  I took a beginner's class and Evan the staff taught me everything I needed plus extra to start climbing. Thanks dude!  I would definitely going back there in regular basis.

Sets the bar for indoor climbing in LA. Tons of terrain and spacious. More climbs than you can possibly approach in one night. Staff members are low-key, share a love for climbing yet with zero of the pretentiousness that plagues other gyms.Key Features:- Lots of varied terrain- Highball climbs- Fresh (new) holdsMinor Gripes: - Membership card is ugly- The logo is poorly designed- Walls seem 1/2 set... could be due to current lack of holds or a lack of regular setters- Parking can get crowded- Membership card is uglyRecommendations:- Create an instagram (or twitter) account that only posts the new sets- Carry 5.10 dragon shoes- Buy chess set and put it atop main boulder for resting chess matches- Create a new membership card that isn't ugly

Biggest bouldering gym in all of LA, kind of a big deal. Currently they are working on adding in a full regular gym as well as yoga classes, so stay tuned friendsEveryone I've met here is super friendly, the whole place has a great vibe. Even though there are people here that obviously kick ass at bouldering, I don't feel deterred for being a n00b. A few times other people there gave me all kinds of advice for freeMy only gripe is the price: $20 for a day pass, $100 for a month. If you sign up long term you get something around $66/mo. That being said, the neighborhood is up and coming so I would imagine rent for such a large building is not cheap

What a fantastic place!   Me and a couple of my buddies visited just last night.  We had a ball.   The facility is super dope and spacious, the staff is friendly and helpful and everything ran like clockwork getting started    Other members were helpful and encouraging and an overall spirit of being "active" and "encouraging abounded.   There were all kinds of different walls and physical challenges, a locker room and a weight room.   It is truly a great place to get your active on!   Thanks for an awesome experience. (It's right around the corner from Yrth Cafe and Barker Block if you are familiar with DTLA Arts Dist.)

Man, an AC climbing gym in LA. I know it's spoiled but whatever. And I like that the easy routes have soft grades. I want  non-climbers to think I can climb V4. Very interestingly laid out problems with a variety of styles. Only gripes - they nickel and dime members for shoes and chalk bags. The hold manufacturer they use - not the amount of variety found elsewhere.

Dope rock climbing gym. The facilities are impeccable. Clean and well-maintained. They also have gym equipment that you can use in a side room and upstairs if you are trying to get a well rounded work out overall. Price is $20 for rock climbing, $4 to rent the shoes, and $1 for a chalk bag. The walls have expertly placed hand and foot holds and there is a plethora of walls with varying degrees of difficulty routes you can try. They have the whole floor padded with soft cushions. Decent amount of parking in the lot. If you just want to hang out inside there is no entry fee and you just have to sign an electronic waiver at the front entrance. Another plus is they play great music throughout the gym.

I took my 3 kids to LA Boulders last week when they were on spring break to give them something to do, we arrived at 2pm and were done in an hour.  The fee is $15 per person so for $60, we got something new and it was physical.  The staff is friendly, they give you a 5 minute safety lesson and point out the areas where you can climb.  Other than me being with my chidren, there is no supervision and no safety harness as you watch your kids climb up to the top at about 12'.  12' appears much higher once your up there so it is thrilling when you have to figure out how to come back down.Parking is a bit tight since there are many other businesses that share the same area so going there off peak times is definately to your advantage.  The area itself is not the greatest but hey, you're in the city of angels and this is expected in this industiral zoned area.  I suggest that you wear loose pants, we wore shorts and our legs got scraped up.  The place is not large and there are only about 4 areas for beginners to climb, other areas are for intermediate and advance climbers.  My kids seemed to like the place the day after our outing than the day of, it seems it was so new to them that they did not know what to think until the experience settled in.  If you are looking for something to do with your kids then I would suggest this place.

As an experienced climber, I found the setting to be very high quality with natural movement, good/new holds, and an optimal route-per-wall ratio. There is a nice sized wall at every angle with very adequate padding. Get into those place and hone your bouldering technique!
I've been to other rock climbing gyms and this is hands down the best. Everyone is friendly and the environment is not intimidating at all
Awesome climbing gym. They change the routes frequently (2 walls per week) to keep it fresh! The staff is always friendly.

I love LA Boulders! I joined about a month ago, so I'm still starting out. I've been to this gym, along with Hollywood Boulders, and Mission Cliffs in SF. This is by far my favorite location (for bouldering). There are high ceilings and great problems- and the routes are always being updated, so I can always count on new problems to work on every week.  I'm not sure if the grading is easier here, but when I climbed at Mission Cliffs the V1's were way harder.  With that said, I think the problems here are really fun, maybe because how high the walls are and how they are structurally designed. The facility is really clean too. The only time I hate coming here is during peak hours, usually in the evenings after people get off of work. There are times when everyone and their entire social groups take up the walls, and as a solo climber it can be kind of annoying. But honestly there is so much space here, and I love spending hours here climbing. Parking can suck at times- I wish they had a bigger lot. But there's makeshift parking along the alleyway, and street parking around the area- just be mindful of the signs!
Greaaaaat spot for bouldering. The climbers are chill, the music selection is choice, and the routes are challenging and diverse. Drop on by for some excellent climbing.

Gym now has filled in all remaining fitness area with gym equipment.  Excellent array of high quality dumbbells, two benches, misc., gear (swiss balls, ab rollers, ankle weights, etc.) downstairs, upstairs packed with various high end cardio gear (probably a bit overkill).  LaB also installed a campus board, wooden hangboard ("Beastmaster"), and another hangboard with uniform edges of increasing depth (never saw one before).The staff has settled into the typical "aloof if there's no business to take care of" gym worker  mode.  From years of experience paying to use indoor rock walls (as well as managing one), I  wouldn't expect anything different but it would be nice to see the management of such a new place mix things up and think a bit harder about customer service from the customer's standpoint.

The ONLY negative thing about this place was the fact that I was charged $4 to rent shoes but after I got the shoes, they were WAY too small. The cashier said that the shoes were the largest they carried and that they were supposed to feel tight but not painful. Didn't get my money back and my toes were in pain while wearing the shoes. Other than that, my wife and I had fun and were very impressed with the atmosphere.

I really like this bouldering gym for it's facilities, but not for it's hours or prices. The staff are okay, but just seem like they're too busy to talk to people most of the time, especially if you're a beginner. Staff aside, the place is very clean and a lot of fun. They have a lot of events so check out their calendar before you leave to see what's coming up. I just really wish they were open earlier. It's a drag that I had to cancel my membership because of the inability to make it there around my schedule. If they could open like 2 or 3 hours earlier, I think it would be a benefit to a lot of other people and not just me. I would be more comfortable paying what I pay if they were open from 8 or 9 am until 11 pm as opposed to 11am-11pm. They provide showers, a locker room, cubbies near the climbing area, Britta water fountain for water bottles and a regular water fountain, weights, a few Elipticals, two rowing machines, a few treadmills and one stationary bike. They also have yoga and guest passes/free initiation days. I'd give it 5 stars if it were open earlier, basically.

The bad:You absolutely have to take a picture when you get your membership. I hate taking pictures. Bonus! They let me take a photo of the back of my head with my bicycle gear on. Parking can be a real pain in the ass. And it doesn't seem like there are any viable alternatives when there isn't any parking in the lot. They close at 6pm on the weekends )8 The problems tend more toward the reachy side. I'm small and not very strong, so I really thrive off of crimps and balance problems. A little more diversity in the route setting would be nice, just so I can feel like I can pat my back a bit. On the bright side, I'm forced to work on problems that focus on my weakness.Steep day pass prices ($20) means it's really difficult to bring my n00b friends with me. I use my guest pass when I can, but since we're really only allotted one per month (not including the 4th or last Friday of the month), I end up feeling bad. But not bad enough to pay the $20 for every person I bring. Obviously... Otherwise the membership is $73 I think and that's pretty reasonable considering the quality of the gym. However since the other Touchstone gyms are up north, that cross over membership doesn't seem to be as useful for LA members. To be fair, I think the membership should be adequately cheaper than the norcal gyms until more LA gyms are opened. The routes are rated soft. But I guess I feel better about myself. Or do I... Bouldering only, but this could be a plus for some. (I'd personally like to be more well-rounded than I am)The good- Brand spanking new facility with walls that are still so sticky they scrap your skin and nab the fine seams of your clothing. Sounds bad, but if your clothes can stick to the wall, so can your shoes. Diverse terrain with a consistent rotation of new problems. Since I've been a member (January), I've seen a rotation of about once per month (not including the comp). Welcoming staff members who are very open to helping you with beta or a spot. They'll know you by name after the first few times and you'll never feel pressured into a membership or any other purchase. Laid back but helpful. (Miss you behind the counter, Allen!) Padded floors everywhere. If you want to walk from point A to point B quickly you'll look like Neil Armstrong.It doesn't smell like feet yet, yay! Fellow climbers are all very friendly, non-competitive, helpful and encouraging. I think because it's a newer gym, it took a while for people to start opening up and getting to know each other but it's recently started to get very open and vibrant.Plenty of space to lock up your bicycle, and sometimes even enough space by the front desk-- though recently the gym has been getting more equipment and more members so this probably won't last very long.They close at 11pm on weekdays.They don't seem too class or children's birthday oriented. Which means! More space, no large groups of n00bs (who know little of wall sharing etiquette) and no feeling sorry for accidentally falling on that small child and hearing "No running!" every 20 seconds. The awesome-When you ask anyone for help on a problem you're too small or too weak for, request that they pretend they are short and not so muscular and they'll do it. With exactness.

Went on a Monday night - not too crowded. They didn't explain anything to us when they got there, but the facilities were good. They had a great variety of courses - spent some time struggling through some v3s, which was fun. Courses are marked well and spaced out enough that if someone is in your area you can always find another. Apparently they close a few days out of the month to set up new courses, usually on Tuesdays or Wednesdays. Always be sure to check before you head over!

I'm quite the critic when it comes to climbing gyms and their bouldering areas since i am primarily a boulderer. But with that being said, this gym has definitely been my favorite gym to boulder at so far in CA. I live 45 mins away and i still make the drive at least once a month to check out the awesome problems. Great setting (for all levels)Great MusicGreat StaffGreat place to be when its too hot to climb outdoors :)

Im rewriting my review after my second visit to lab. I really enjoy the walltopia walls and general terrain here. The gym upstairs and general facilities are pretty awesome. The walls them selves do not lend them selves for the use of large features, which is disappointing. I'm rating this place a three stars because of their employees. A group of us were climbing the other night and witnessed what many people refer to as the "count down", where one of their employees yells out how much time before you have to leave! Climbing at my local gym I've never, ever even been asked to leave when closing was approaching. I get the feeling from. These employees that they are too cool, for the likes of us little people. So go in, check it out but remember hipsters have an air about them.
This place is great- PHENOMENAL. Great place to climb without any pretensions and fun to watch people. There's a gym, a shower, multiple walls and both street and lot parking. Great Place.

I had been going to Touchstone Gyms in the Bay Area since 2005 or so, so I was SOOO psyched when they opened up LA Boulders. I love bouldering and this place delivers. There's always a new route to try and they do a good job of keeping the walls fresh. Super excited for the other gyms they're opening up in the LA area as well (Hollywood and Culver City). Can't wait to get in some top-rope!This particular gym does have a limited weight and cardio/stretch area. But I think they're going to expand these options in the next two gyms they're opening. I also wish the gym opened earlier, since I'm a morning exerciser and prefer to work out on a relatively empty stomach. By the time people get off of work and we go climb, it pushes dinner back to like 9-10pm...It gets super busy on Tuesday and Thursday nights... and parking can be a pain... One night I parked a block away and kept worrying whether my car was going to get broken into.

Other than the hub in Markham, this is the nicest bouldering gym I have been to. Some of the top out is a bit sketched, but overall super fun, the route seems to change decently often, with different things to work on.
first time coming to this place the guy at the front desk was great hooked us up for the first it was fun and i will go back again soon

Great bouldering gym! Clean holds, well set/ decent variety of routes and friendly crowd. They also have some weight lifting equipment, ellipticals, lockers and showers. The prices are a bit steep and I'd love to see some yoga classes offered but over all I like the place.

One of the best climbing gyms I've been to! Great routes and great variety in difficulty. Whether you're looking for a V0 or a V7, or even higher, you'll find plenty. Also a great selection of gym equipment. Up to date treadmills, ellipticals, weights, etc. Locker rooms were very clean! Nothing broken, rusty or dirty. Very nice showers. Amazing gym and climbing experience! :)

This place is preeeeeeeety cool. Wide open climbing spaces AND small areas upstairs and downstairs to lift weights and warm-up with rowing machines, treadmills, and ellipticals. Climbing here will help improve your upper-body strength in a fun way without you realizing it! Sucks I'm so far away from it, but will definitely be going back.

It was my first time. Guy up front asked me if I needed any help, but I was waiting for a friend who'd been before. I like the added gym element. Clean bathrooms. I had a great time and am waiting for my body not to be sore so I can go back asap.

Excellent spot with a great community, I almost don't want to write a review because I want to keep it a secret. There's awesome climbs for someone who's a beginner like me plus a bunch of crazy ish for those more advanced.
We've been members here for several months now, and we love it! The staff is great, and they switch up the routes pretty regularly. I'm also digging the new pads they put in not too long ago.

It is a great place! very fun. I hope they open at earlier time really soon. The 3stars is just cuz of the business hours, limited parking spots, and also members have to pay for rental shoes! also, the yoga classes or additional workout classes they had promised have not existed yet.Membership is quite pricey, but I think it is worth it. Other than that, coolest bouldering gym in LA area!! woot woot :)
large space, good setting and really great facilities. very helpful staff and never too busy!

The best workout I've had in years...and I lift weights about 3-4 times a week. An awesome way to hang out with friends, solve puzzles and get a kick-ass workout. The only reason anyone ever leaves is pure exhaustion.
easily the best bouldering gym in southern california. beautiful and diverse walls, friendly people. landing pads are great unlike sender one for people falling off or people with knee problems.

Best bouldering in a gym I have seen.  Problems are thoughtful and challenging.   Staff is great.  Air conditioning is huge for me.  And they change the problems frequently.  I absolutely love this LA.B and would recommend it for anyone.

Finally we have a real gym that is as good as the european gyms, if not Better.  This place brand new holds!  Also is very kid friendly.  Signing up and registering is high tech.  The staff is super fun and helpful.  Look forward to many visits here.  This is my new hang out home!!!
